summary: Email chain between FBI personnel and a US Attorney's Office (NY) coordinator regarding the transfer and identification of electronic devices (iPhones, iPads, a hard drive, and a thumb drive) seized from an individual at the time of arrest. The correspondence focuses on confirming which specific devices are duplicated across different storage media.

persons.name: M. I.
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner (FBI)
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the transfer and identification of seized electronic devices (iPhones, iPads) to the US Attorney's Office in New York.

persons.name: Mina
persons.context: Recipient of an email forwarding the device coordination discussion; appears to be copied on the correspondence.

connections.description: Working together to coordinate and confirm the transfer of seized electronic evidence from an arrest.

events.title: Device evidence transfer coordination
events.description: FBI forensic examiner M.I. drops off a hard drive containing data from 6 iPads and a phone seized from an individual at arrest, and corresponds with the US Attorney's Office to confirm which items are duplicates of previously submitted evidence.

keyFacts: Electronic devices, including iPhones and iPads, were seized from an individual at the time of their arrest.
An FBI forensic examiner coordinated the transfer of this device data to the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS).
The correspondence clarifies that a hard drive contained data from 6 iPads and the phone the individual had on him at arrest, while an old iPhone 5 was still being unlocked at FBI HQ.
The emails are subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence.
